articles.headline: Microsoft Sues Justice Department to Protest Electronic Gag Order Statute
articles.snippet: The company is challenging the use of secrecy orders that prevent it from telling people when the government obtains a warrant to read their emails.
articles.abstract: The company is challenging the use of secrecy orders that prevent it from telling people when the government obtains a warrant to read their emails.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big technology companies have usually played a defensive game with government prosecutors in their legal fight over customer information, fighting or bowing to requests for information one case at a time.

articles.headline: How Regulators Mess With Bankers’ Minds, and Why That’s Good
articles.snippet: Not communicating to banks exactly what they need to do to get their bankruptcy plans to pass muster is frustrating, confusing and part of the plan.
articles.abstract: Not communicating to banks exactly what they need to do to get their bankruptcy plans to pass muster is frustrating, confusing and part of the plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank regulators on Wednesday sent a message that big banks are still too big and too complex. They rejected special plans, called living wills, that the banks have to submit to show they can go through an orderly bankruptcy.

articles.headline: The S.U.V. Arms Race Goes Upscale
articles.snippet: As the profits flow in from sport utility vehicles, automakers are aiming for the luxury market, with fancy new models in development or already in showrooms.
articles.abstract: As the profits flow in from sport utility vehicles, automakers are aiming for the luxury market, with fancy new models in development or already in showrooms.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the last big profit centers for Detroit’s automakers, the sport utility vehicle, is under siege.

articles.headline: In Brexit Debate, English Fishermen Eye Waters Free of E.U.
articles.snippet: As the vote on “Brexit” nears, an English Channel port is leaning toward Britain’s leaving the European Union and regaining control of its fishing grounds.
articles.abstract: As the vote on “Brexit” nears, an English Channel port is leaning toward Britain’s leaving the European Union and regaining control of its fishing grounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRIXHAM, England — Mike Walker, a retired fisherman here, sums up what many in this southern English port town think of the European Union.

articles.headline: Before Trump Campaign, Corey Lewandowski Rode Herd on a Town’s Leaders
articles.snippet: Mr. Lewandowski monitored the government of Windham, N.H., even uncovering a fantasy football email scandal that brought down a prosecutor.
articles.abstract: Mr. Lewandowski monitored the government of Windham, N.H., even uncovering a fantasy football email scandal that brought down a prosecutor.
articles.lead_paragraph: To Ross McLeod, a prosecutor and selectman in the town of Windham, N.H., it was a harmless hobby: running a small fantasy football league with a handful of friends and a pot of around $200 a year.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Jess Bidgood

articles.headline: Yahoo’s Suitors Uncover Few Financial Details
articles.snippet: Potential buyers for Yahoo’s businesses are wondering just what is for sale.
articles.abstract: Potential buyers for Yahoo’s businesses are wondering just what is for sale.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As Yahoo prepares to accept first-round bids for its core Internet business on Monday, potential buyers have found themselves facing one big problem: How do you value a company with a declining business when the company appears reluctant to share vital financial details?
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Dilma Rousseff Targeted in Brazil by Lawmakers Facing Scandals of Their Own
articles.snippet: Many of the legislators calling for President Rousseff’s impeachment are facing charges that some observers say are more serious than the accusations against her.
articles.abstract: Many of the legislators calling for President Rousseff’s impeachment are facing charges that some observers say are more serious than the accusations against her.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — Paulo Maluf, a Brazilian congressman, is so badly besieged by his own graft scandals that his constituents often describe him with the slogan “Rouba mas faz.” Translation: He steals but gets it done.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Vinod Sreeharsha

articles.headline: In Democratic Debate, Clinton and Sanders Spar Over Judgment
articles.snippet: Bernie Sanders repeatedly savaged Hillary Clinton’s ties to wealthy donors and Wall Street banks, while Mrs. Clinton countered with steely confidence.
articles.abstract: Bernie Sanders repeatedly savaged Hillary Clinton’s ties to wealthy donors and Wall Street banks, while Mrs. Clinton countered with steely confidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders, seizing on potential vulnerabilities for Hillary Clinton in the coming New York primary, repeatedly savaged her ties to wealthy donors and Wall Street banks during their debate on Thursday night, delivering a ferocious performance that Mrs. Clinton countered with steely confidence and her own sharp elbows.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Obama Presses for Open Market for Cable Set-Top Boxes
articles.snippet: The president weighed in on a proposal at the Federal Communications Commission, filing comments that encourage the agency to loosen cable companies’ grip.
articles.abstract: The president weighed in on a proposal at the Federal Communications Commission, filing comments that encourage the agency to loosen cable companies’ grip.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday announced his support for opening the market for cable set-top boxes, singling out the devices in millions of homes as a clunky and outdated symbol of corporate power over consumers, as he introduced a broad federal effort to increase competition.

articles.headline: Reclaiming Fees When Airline Luggage Goes Astray
articles.snippet: The frustrating struggle when you try to get your money back — and the new legislation that could help travelers.
articles.abstract: The frustrating struggle when you try to get your money back — and the new legislation that could help travelers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buried in the new bill reauthorizing the Federal Aviation Administration are a few sections addressing the fees that many of us pay to fly. And while the Senate and the House bills still differ a bit, one likely result is going to be this: The carriers are going to have to refund the fees you pay when your luggage isn’t on your flight and you have to wait a long time to get it.

articles.headline: BlackRock Wields Its Big Stick Like a Wet Noodle on C.E.O. Pay
articles.snippet: The world’s largest investment manager has the power to change companies’ short-terms ways by voting to curb C.E.O. pay, but it rarely exercises it.
articles.abstract: The world’s largest investment manager has the power to change companies’ short-terms ways by voting to curb C.E.O. pay, but it rarely exercises it.
articles.lead_paragraph: For several years, Laurence D. Fink, chairman and chief executive of BlackRock, the money management giant, has been on a crusade, exhorting corporations to change their short-term ways. Executives should forgo tricks that reward short-term stock traders, he argues, like share buybacks purchased at high valuations. Instead, corporate managers should focus on creating value for long-term shareholders.

articles.headline: As China’s Growth Slows, Banks Feel the Strain of Bad Debt
articles.snippet: Chinese lenders feel rising pain from souring loans in troubled industries — even as they face pressure to keep local companies afloat.
articles.abstract: Chinese lenders feel rising pain from souring loans in troubled industries — even as they face pressure to keep local companies afloat.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For Chinese banks, the decision to lend to companies like Bohai Steel was for years a no-brainer. Lenders took heart from its state backing, which appeared as solid as the millions of tons of steel pipes that rolled off its production lines each year.
